alfredsnippet.snippet:
p29-30:

"It matters little as to how many 'millions of years' scientists attempt to ascribe to the cycles of the Sahara or where they place them in time and space, it is very apparent we have a recurring circular problem, since the more it rains the more erosion takes place and the more erosion, the more the rivers and lakes silt up (and the more the source areas become shielded) ...

... unless scientists are suggesting that the alternating wet and dry cycles have now ceased, then we are currently amidst a dry period. Now, what would happen if we were to theoretically wind the clock forward to the next wet episode -- a time when, as before, North Africa is once again subjected to a plentiful supply of rainwater? ... Given enough time and plenty of water, areas of little sand would no doubt turn green again, probably quite rapidly, but what of the sand? Where would all the sand go?"
alfredsnippet.name: Phys.org Post - Extraterrestrial Sands - Part 03
